case_title: Mst. MARZIA SULTANA vs TEE STATE

accussed_details.name: Mst. Marzia Sultana
allegation: Violation of Land Reforms Regulation No. 64 of 1959, Paragraph 25

complaint_summary: The Land Commissioner, Sargodha Division, declared 13 land mutations by Mst. Marzia Sultana as void, alleging they violated Paragraph 25 of the repealed Land Reforms Regulation No. 64 of 1959 by reducing her holding below an economic threshold.
investigation_summary: The case was referred to a Legal Adviser for inquiry. The appellant's attorney argued that the transactions were valid as they complied with sub-paragraph 6 of Paragraph 25 of M.L.R. 64, allowing alienation for residential purposes. The appellant's remaining land was disposed of entirely on 16-05-1970.
judgment_summary: The Board of Revenue set aside the Land Commissioner's order, holding that the transactions were valid and not in violation of Paragraph 25(3) of M.L.R. 64. The appeal was allowed, and the mutations were reinstated.
legal_arguments: The appellant's attorney argued that the land transactions were valid as they complied with sub-paragraph 6 of Paragraph 25 of M.L.R. 64, which permits alienation for residential purposes.
The attorney contended that the remaining land was disposed of entirely on 16-05-1970, making the transactions compliant with Paragraph 25(3) of M.L.R. 64.
assets: 477 kanals and 8 marlas of agricultural land in Village Rajana, Tehsil and District Jhang
sections: Paragraph 25 of Land Reforms Regulation No. 64 of 1959

key_issues: Validity of land mutations under Land Reforms Regulation No. 64 of 1959
Reduction of holding below economic threshold

legal_terms.Mutation: A change or transfer in the ownership of land.
legal_terms.Economic Holding: A minimum area of land required for economic viability.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the validity of 13 land mutations executed by Mst. Marzia Sultana. The Land Commissioner declared them void under Paragraph 25 of the repealed Land Reforms Regulation No. 64 of 1959, arguing they reduced her holding below an economic threshold. The Board of Revenue overturned this decision, finding the transactions compliant with the law, particularly for residential purposes. The appeal was allowed, reinstating the mutations.
